byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin, James Kanter from Brussels, and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura from Sunderland, England.
byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAN BILEFSKY

abstract: European Union leaders urge Great Britain to begin process of leaving bloc immediately following vote in favor of Brexit, while reeling Britain shows signs of seeking slower transition; Prime Min David Cameron, reluctant to oversee process he opposed, indicates process may have to wait until his replacement is chosen in October, while conservative leaders say it may not happen until there are more negotiations with EU; bloc's guidelines do not specify when Britain must leave.
lead_paragraph: There were clear indications Saturday of a tense and bickering divorce, as European leaders urged Britain to hurry up and begin its departure.

headline.main: European Leaders Tell a Dazed Britain to Get Going on ‘Brexit’
headline.print_headline: Europe Urges Dazed Britain to Get Moving

snippet: There were clear indications Saturday of a tense and bickering divorce, as European leaders urged Britain to hurry up and begin its departure.
